      COX NEWS SERVICE FRIDAY FEATURES BUDGET
      c. 1998 Cox News Service

   These feature stories for release Friday, June 5, 1998, are
moving today to clients of the New York Times News Service.

   Separate budgets move daily with spot news, sports, business and
commentary.

   Stories are moving in the category they're listed under. Stories
moving to duplicate categories are marked. All stories have moved
except those with an ETA.

   If you have questions or need a resend, please call CoxNet, the
Cox News Service, at 404-526-5456.

   LIFESTYLE

   BLACKWHITE _ ATLANTA _ People do many things to stand out in a
crowd. Joel Bethea and Kelvin Lawrence simply went to high school.
Bethea is one of two white students graduating this month from
Southwest DeKalb High, and Lawrence is one of six black students in
his senior class at Pope High in the suburb of East Cobb. On June
13, they both will celebrate their high-school graduation. They
admit it wasn't always easy being a white face in a black crowd or
vice versa. But they didn't just survive their four years of high
school, they thrived. Here's how. (Harrison, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA: 7 p.m.

   CONSUMER-COLUMN _ Information on shredded dollars, the Salt Lake
City Olympics, Texas loan laws, baby carriage wheels, and more.
Weekly consumer column from Austin. (Greig, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   BABY-GRAULICH _ As my pregnancy advanced, the baby daze got
worse. Where the brain goes, apparently, the will to move follows.
I had become a human paperweight. The Book explains all of this.
``What to Expect When You're Expecting,'' the pregnant woman's
operating manual, warns of ``a feeling you're not quite together.
You're a scatterbrain, you forget things, drop things'' starting in
the fourth month. (Graulich, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   PLATFORM _ Size matters. These days, ``summer'' is just another
word for ``blockbuster.'' And the platform sandals that look so
right for this season have blockbuster stamped on their soles.
(Walton, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/3. EMBARGOED UNTIL
6/7.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS (e category)

   TV-SURFER _ Quick chat with TBS' ``Dinner & a Movie'' hosts Paul
Gilmartin and Annabelle Gurwitch, who've taped several new spots
for June and July, including June 12's ``Sleeping With The Enemy''
(the recipe: Pecan Someone Your Own Size Pie). (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA: 7 p.m.

   TALES-REVIEW _ Review of Showtime's ``More Tales of the City''
from Armistead Maupin airing Sunday. Grade: B+. (Jubera, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA: 7 p.m.

   MOVIE REVIEWS (Unless already moved, ETA on all: 4 p.m. ET):

   TRUMAN-REVIEW _ Jim Carrey plays man whose whole life is the
subject of a constantly running TV documentary. (Schwan, Palm Beach
Post) MOVED.

   TRUMAN-CARREY _ Profile/interview with Carrey. (Ringel, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   TRUMAN-LINNEY _Interview with Laura Linney, who plays Jim
Carrey's wife in ``The Truman Show,'' and revives her role as Mary
Anne Singleton in cable's ``More Tales of the City'' later this
month. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   DISCO _ ``Last Days of Disco.'' (Schwan, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   MURDER-REVIEW _ ``A Perfect Murder,'' with Michael Douglas and
Gwynneth Paltrow. Grade: B.(Atlanta Journal-Constitution) ETA 8
p.m. ET.

   COITUM-REVIEW _ ``Post-Coitum.'' (Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   DIRTYWORK-REVIEW _ ``Dirty Work.'' (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) ETA 8 p.m. ET.

   BOOKS

   BOOKS-NOTES _ In the early 1980s, James Kilgo was presented with
a tantalizing story that no writer could resist. Kilgo faced a
dilemma of either telling the true story and hurting some family
members or casting it as a novel. He took the fictional route. The
result is ``Daughter of My People'' (University of Georgia Press,
$24), Kilgo's debut novel, which early reviews have described as
``sad, vivid, and haunting.'' (And other news on books.) (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/3.

   FOOD (d food)

   FOOD-CRAWFISH _ BREAUX BRIDGE, La. _ No one is ashamed of
crawfish nowadays. Not only do people peel and suck them right out
in the open, they celebrate them at events like the crawfish
festival they've held every May since 1960 in Breaux Bridge, a town
of 6,000 near Lafayette. The little crustacean has become a big red
banner of Cajun pride, a cultural trademark as distinctive as a
spicy French drawl or a jumping accordion on Saturday night. Mr.
Mudbug has gone to town. (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)
MOVED 6/3. EMBARGOED UNTIL 6/7.

   WITH

   CRAWFISH-RECIPES _ Ailene Champagne Guidry didn't create the
most famous crawfish dish; people from Baton Rouge to Lake Charles
had long been cooking something like it. She did, however, make an
early version of it and give it a name. And that's why her
sepia-toned portrait hangs in a place of honor in the Cafe des
Amis, a restaurant on the main street of Breaux Bridge. This is a
simpler, kitchenized version of the Cafe des Amis etouffee. (Recipe
follows.) (Auchmutey, Atlanta Journal-Constitution) MOVED 6/3.
EMBARGOED UNTIL 6/7.

   SCIENCE/MEDICINE

   FAUX-PSYCHOLOGIST _ WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. _ School therapist
Linda Werner passed herself off as a clinical psychologist even
though she was never licensed. Werner said under oath in 1994 that
she was a ``licensed clinical psychologist'' who had testified as
an expert in at least 250 cases and been appointed by judges 30 to
40 times. Judges relied on her testimony to decide whether parents
were capable of raising children and how marital assets should be
divided. (McLachlin, Palm Beach Post) MOVED.

   Story Filed By Cox Newspapers
